issues.description: The problem statement requires Farm to hold its animals in a List and explicitly instructs to implement it using an ArrayList (Part 3, lines describing aggregation). The solution implementation, however, uses a Queue<Animal> backed by a LinkedList (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java). This creates a structural mismatch: the field type, constructor initialization, and getter/setter signatures in the solution differ from the data structure (List/ArrayList) specified in the exercise. Students following the problem text (or automated tests expecting List/ArrayList types and methods) could be confused or unable to match the reference implementation or tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Farm implementation consistent with the problem specification: declare the animals attribute as a List<Animal>, initialize it with new ArrayList<>() in the no-argument constructor, and update the getter/setter signatures to use List<Animal>. Adjust addAnimal(), feedAllAnimals(), and singFarmSong() implementations to operate on a List. Alternatively (less preferred), update the problem statement to accept Queue/LinkedList if that design is intentional — but prefer aligning the solution with the stated requirement to use List/ArrayList.

issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires Farm to hold its animals in a List implemented using an ArrayList and to provide corresponding getter/setter. The solution implementation instead declares the collection as a Queue<Animal> and initializes it with a LinkedList. This changes the type identifier (List/ArrayList vs Queue/LinkedList) for the same conceptual entity (the collection of animals) and can confuse students: they are told to use List/ArrayList but the reference solution uses different collection types and names.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution use the same collection type named in the problem statement: change the farm field to List<Animal> animals, initialize it with new ArrayList<>(); and update the getter/setter signatures to use List<Animal>. This aligns identifiers (List/ArrayList) across problem, template, and solution and avoids unnecessary mapping effort for students.
